text:
BRIAN KENNY: Welcome to
Managing Through Crisis,

the webcast featuring
faculty from Harvard Business

School sharing insights for
managers on how to navigate
through the COVID-19 crisis.

As we enter the month
of May, five months

deep into the pandemic, many
countries around the world,

including the US, are
experimenting with loosening
restrictions on self-isolation.

Health care experts
say it's a risky move,

but experts looking at
the economic indicators

say it's essential to get
business back up and running.

Business leaders find themselves
in the middle of that tension,

trying to balance the welfare
of employees and customers

with the necessities
of generating revenue

to pay those workers and
to keep the lights on.

It's a challenge
the likes of which

we've literally
never seen before.

But there may be some lessons
we can take from the past.

And today, we're very fortunate
to have Professor Ranjay Gulati
here to discuss some insights.

Ranjay has studied, taught and
written about organizations
and leaders for decades.

And he knows the hallmarks
of great leadership.

Ranjay, thanks so much
for joining me today.
Great to be here with you.
RANJAY GULATI: Thank you, Brian.

My pleasure to be
here and have a chance

to share my thoughts
with all of you.

BRIAN KENNY: We had
some great questions

come in from our audience,
and I'm going to get to those.

But I thought I would
start just by asking
you to reflect a little bit.

Over the years, you've
worked with many leaders,

you've taught so many in our
executive education program.

You've got to be familiar
with the common traits of what

it takes to lead
in turbulent times.

And I know you've been
thinking a lot about this.

Can you just
describe what you see
as sort of the commonalities?

RANJAY GULATI:
Well, I think it's

important to
understand when we face

these kinds of turbulent
times, if you will,

there are usually a couple
of triggers that kick in.

The first thing that
kicks in is what

looks like risk turns
into uncertainty.

And I want to go back to some
Nobel Prize-winning research

here on the distinction
between risk and uncertainty.

Your risk is where you have a
known distribution of outcomes,

you can put some
probabilities to it,

and you're trying
to manage risk.

Uncertainty is
where you don't know
the distribution of outcomes.
You don't really know.

And I think what
happens over here

is we are facing a situation
of unprecedented uncertainty
in some ways.

And when you combine that
with loss of control, meaning,
I can't even--

I don't have a sense
of control over here.

I can't control what's
going to happen.

I don't know when we're
going to have a vaccine.

I don't know when social
distancing needs to be lifted.

We don't know what the
treatment's going to look like.

So you have uncertainty
with loss of control.

And what do we know from
when those things collide,
we activate fear.

Fear is that kind of
emotional response
to situations like this.

So that's one part
of the puzzle.

The other part of
the puzzle, which

ties to this
emotional response is

we tend to go into
a defensive posture.

It's about hunker down,
survival, protect.

And we're no longer
playing offense.

In business, we teach about
playing offense and defense.

So what we have is a
situation of uncertainty,

of loss of control,
hunker down, survival.

BRIAN KENNY: So you wrote
about this actually.

Not about this pandemic,
but you wrote about this

after the Fukushima
incident, the tsunami that

took place in Japan after
the terrible earthquake.

I think it's 2014, somewhere
around that time frame.
And you did an article in HBR.

I read that because you
sent it to me in preparation
for this conversation.

And I was really struck by how
many common themes came out

of that article that
would apply today.

Can you talk a
little bit about what

we can learn from
how they managed

that situation at the
power plant in Fukushima?

RANJAY GULATI: So
the one thing I

found interesting in that
story was, at one level,

that story, at face
value, is about four days.

It's about a
four-day crisis where

they have to deal with
an unprecedented-- again,
an unusual, bizarre situation.
They had no scenario planning.

But it's not just about
managing through the crisis.
It's kind of also how do they--

the crisis piece kind of ended
in about a day and a half

because there were--
aftershocks were dying down.

Now they had to do
something about it.

And so let's just kind of
walk through-- the idea

here was how does a leader
help his people navigate
through these uncertain times?

The temptation is to
either go heavy top down,

or the other extreme is,
we don't know what to do.
Does anybody have any ideas?

Let's start crowdsourcing ideas,
which doesn't work either.

So how do you find
the right balance

between where you are inclusive
and directive at the same time?

How do you support people
but direct them too?

How do you challenge
them, but also show them
consideration and understanding?

So you have a leader
here who has to manage
through a delicate situation.

Again, what looks like
a four-day scenario

I think is relevant
here because I

think we are beyond
crisis mode right now.

We're in that what people
are calling new abnormal when

we are not out of the woods, or
we're no longer in crisis mode

anymore, but when
this kind of limbo

stage where we don't know when
this thing is going to end.

So I think the story is not just
about acute crisis, oh, my god,
what do I do?

It's really about, OK, now
how do I get us through it?

BRIAN KENNY: So in
that context, how

do leaders think about
this, this real tension

that I mentioned in
my introduction, which

is they've got to care, first
and foremost, about the welfare

of their workers,
of their customers

if they're in a brick
and mortar, let's say.

But they've also got to
think about the business
and the health of the business.

And that's a really
difficult tension to balance.

How should leaders be
thinking about that?
RANJAY GULATI: Yeah.

Well, look I think you've
heard this enough times,

I think, is that
of course, people

want to hear that
you care about them,

that their welfare
and well-being
is extremely important to you.

And I think in the
day and age where

people are talking about
businesses having a purpose,

we are talking about
purpose-driven organizations

where purpose is no longer
just shareholder value.

People are-- expect
more of their employer.

And I think this is that moment
we're going to step up and say,

I'm going to find a way
to navigate and balance

the needs of the business
with the needs of my customers
with the needs of my employees.
And these are hard trade offs.
It's not an easy answer.

There isn't a magical
win-win where everybody
gets everything they want.

There are going to be
some hard trade offs.

And what I think the Fukushima
story tells us is the leader

does a great job and not just
to communicating his decision,

but he involves them in the
thought process by which he
came to that decision.

So he provided some
transparency of intentionality,

transparency around the
deliberation he went through,

and then people understand
why he decided what he
decided to do in that moment.

And that was a way for
him to carry everybody
with him, saying--

and he also acknowledges, this
may not be the right decision,
and I may have to reverse it.

So but in this moment with
the information I have,

this is what I think is the
best course of action for us.

BRIAN KENNY: Well,
one of our viewers

asked a pretty simple
question, but I

thought, a pretty
powerful one, which

is, how do we know
when a leader is not
doing well in a time like this?

Are there signs we should be
looking for that maybe somebody

not holding up the
way that they need to?

RANJAY GULATI: That's a
great question and, I think,

one that I think we all
should be asking ourselves.
What am I not doing?

And I think, first of
all, leaders at this time

want to be not the
invisible leader.

You want to be the
visible leader.

They want to feel you
as connected to them.

They want to feel that
you are empathetic towards

their plight, whether they are
customers or your employees
or other stakeholders.
You've got to be out there.

So first of all, leaders
is about being visible.

And the next part of
it is being proactive,

and be willing to take decisions
with incomplete information.

We have a great story that
Carl Weick, a famous scholar

from Michigan, talks
about, about these soldiers

who got lost in the
Alps in the 1930s.

And they were
completely demoralized.
They were running out of food.

And they didn't have a map, so
they didn't know what to do.

And the snowstorm
wasn't abating.

And so they're taking stock
and they finally found a map.

And this map was a game
changer in their minds.

So they looked at the map and
they said, OK, we're here.
Let's go back.

And when they got back, they
got back and their commander

who was waiting for
them said, oh, my god, I
thought you were dead.
What happened?

They pulled out the map and
says, here's where we were.

And the commander looks
at the map and says,

guys, this is a map of
the Pyrenees mountains.
It's not the Alps.

But I think-- so
having the wrong map
even is better than no map.

So I think people want to
feel they're being directed,

they want to feel
they're being heard,

they want to feel
they're being supported.
And it's OK to make mistakes.

Well, mistakes, meaning
updated decisions,

and ability to kind of
navigate and adjust.

And there was a great
book by Eccles and Nohria,

long time ago, called,
Beyond the Hype,

where they talk about this
research on chess players.

And the grand masters,
what they do well is,

not only do they
think moves ahead,

but-- regular chess
players do as well--

is they take what they
call robust action.

They make the move
that gives them

maximum flexibility
for the next move,

depending on what their
opponent might do.

So we're looking at
a situation where

we're looking for robust
action, but we're also

communicating that clearly to
the people who work with us.

BRIAN KENNY: It's
actually a great segue

to the next question
I want to ask you.

One of our viewers
asked, as we turn

to the future, what
are the kinds of things

that leaders need to be
signaling about the return?

We know it's not
going to be normal.

We know it's not going to be
the normal that we knew before.

We add in this element
of working from home.

We've learned things
about ourselves
that we didn't know before.

We've learned that we're capable
of things that we didn't know.

How should the leaders be
signaling to their teams

about what the next phase of
this is going to look like?

RANJAY GULATI: So
I think there's
a couple of parts to this.

The first thing that I
learned from another piece

I had done in HBR called,
Roaring out of Recessions--

and in that piece, the one
thing I learned about companies

and down markets was the
winners-- there's only 9%

of companies that come
out of down times ahead.

And the post-recession
performance

is far superior to what they
were going into the recession.

And what these
companies do is they

master the ability
to engage in what
we call defense and offense.

How do you do them
both simultaneously?
And it's not easy.

It's like saying
I'm going to hit

the accelerator and the brake
at the same time in my car.

And I think as companies need
to take a defensive posture--

and I think the
idea is how are they

saying to themselves
that, listen,

we need to play offense and
defense in these markets.

The other thing is
what you might call it
a learning orientation.

How can we use this adversity
to make ourselves better?

Because adversity is time and
people are willing to adjust,
change.

Somehow we-- all the
barriers we have go down.
We're more receptive to change.

So the punchline of that article
was never waste a crisis.
Never waste a crisis.

And so how are you
going to use this crisis
to come out stronger?

What are the bets
you're placing?

How are you thinking of
revitalizing your organization?

How are you building
deeper commitments
with your employees?

There's a lot you can be
doing in these down times.

BRIAN KENNY: But that's
tricky because you

don't want to appear
to be too opportunistic
in a time like this.

Is it correct, I
guess, to be looking
at new business opportunities?

Or is that what a
leader should be doing?

I mean, should they be directing
their team to say, look,

we're going to find the silver
lining in this situation.

That's a tricky
thing to balance.
RANJAY GULATI: It's tricky.

And I'll tell you, that's why
it's only 9% of companies.

It's tricky for another reason,
because you're sometimes

having to take from
Peter to give to Paul.

You're going to say, I'm
going to cut your budget 20%,

but I'm going to
invest over here

because I see-- and I
think these are very, very
challenging and hard decisions.

And some growth is
organic, some is inorganic.

But the idea-- and I think
the important thing to realize

is one is to explore
growth opportunities, which
is the one playing offense.

The other one is how do we
refresh our organization?

How do we hit a reset
in our organization?

What are the things we
really want to be good at?

What of the things
we're not doing?

It's also a time crisis when
you are there for your customers
and for your employees.

It's also a time when people
feel much more connected.

When you are there for others
in those kind of down moments,
people don't forget easily.

So how do we deepen that
connectivity with our people,
with our customers?

How do we use this as a time
to engage in selective growth?

And you're right
about one thing,

there are some things
that are going to change.
For instance, travel.

We're going to have a
fundamental reset on--

even if we have a
vaccine, even if we

have a robust treatment
for this virus,
there's going to be less travel.

People will say, I
can do it by Zoom,

or whatever medium you're using,
or Teams or something or Webex.

You're going to say
that, look, hygiene
is going to become important.

Governments are going to spend
much more on health care.

And we're never going to
have ICU overloads that
were going to build up.

So there's some things
that are naturally

going to be changing in
work rhythms and sectors.

And I think we should
all be thinking

about that, that we're not going
to go back to same old same.

I don't think that's
going to happen.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.
You mentioned governments.

Do you think that given
all the interplay between--

we'll just stick in the US for
a moment-- between the Trump

administration and the business
leaders and some businesses

turning on a dime to be able
to change their business,

essentially, to support the
needs that are out there,

does this signal a
fundamental change

in the way business
leaders see their role

as participating in the
governmental process
and policymaking?

RANJAY GULATI: So there's a--
two parts to that question.

One is there's a general
issue of agility and speed.

Agility, as a buzzword,
has been around now.

For the last five, seven years,
people are talking about,
we need to become more agile.
And agile is an old word.
Agile programming.

Agile-- it's been around, but
it was the new new thing five,
seven years ago.

But it was based on a
very simple understanding.

The late Jack Welch once said
that if a business is not

changing at least as fast as
the environment around it,

it's only a matter of
time before it's gone.

And so yes, we have
much more turbulence,

we have much more change,
technological, regulatory.

And now we have a
health care change.

So businesses have to
adjust and adapt for sure.

So that's going to happen,
whether it's pivoting fast,

whether it's moving, taking
or doing cost correction.
And it's interesting for me.

I find it's hard, not
only for large companies,
it's hard for small companies.

I found pivoting
is hard for small--

once you have a
winning formula, you

don't know how to
[CLICKS] redirect.

But the second part
of your question

is about government and
business interactions.

And I think we all understand
that what this time is going

to make us think very carefully
about how collaboratively we

must work with the
governments we're involved in.

You're going to see
movements, possibly

towards the globalization
of supply chains.

People are going to say, hey,
I don't want to have my supply

chain somewhere else, overseas,
on certain critical things.

You're going to see that
with regulatory barriers put
in place around something.

So there's going to be
some readjustment that
is going to happen after this.

And I think to get through
that in a productive way,

we're going to have to have
a collaborative understanding
between business and government.

And this also poses the larger
question that has been looming.

And my colleague, Rebecca
Henderson, has a new book out--

I wanted to do a
shout out for her--
on reimagining capitalism.

And that larger question
of what is the role
of business in society?
I think we are all going to be--
we've been talking about it.

Larry Fink talked
about it in his letters
to public company CEOs.

I think this is going to
become even more front
and center in the years ahead.

How can business
engage with society
beyond just shareholder value?
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

We actually had Rebecca on this
very program a few weeks ago,

and she talked about
some of those ideas.

I think the book is going
to be-- it's so timely.

I think it's going to
be big-- a big hit.

So I've got one more
question for you

and then we'll let you
get back to your work.

Your favorite CEO calls
you up and says, Ranjay,
this is really tough.

We're going through
some tough times here.

What's one piece of
advice you can give me
to help me weather this storm?
What would that be?

RANJAY GULATI: The one piece
of advice I would give--
that's a good question--

is, I think we talk a lot about
businesses having purpose.
Why are we here?

Who will miss us if we
are no longer in business?

And I think it's in
moments like this

that we have to be
living her purpose.
And I don't just mean doing CSR.

I don't just mean
writing checks.

Purpose is a much bigger
idea than just doing
CSR on the side.

It's about the core of
why we choose to be.

And I think businesses have
understood that we, of course,
exist for an economic reason.

We want to create unique value
that nobody else can create
for the markets we're in.

But we also realize, as
another colleague, Mike Porter

and Kramer, have talked
about shared value,

that we have to look for ways
to connect with other goals
that we can serve.

And that includes
serving employees.
That includes serving customers.

That includes serving
the community.

That includes
serving the planet.

And I think if there
ever was a good time

to remind yourself of
why we choose to exist,
and that is now.

And I hope that
that purpose is what

should be the directing force
for any organization trying
to find their way through this.

BRIAN KENNY: I hope there are
some CEOs listening because I
think that's great advice.

Ranjay Gulati, thank you so
much for joining us today.
RANJAY GULATI: Thank you.
My pleasure.

Nice to be with all of you, and
all my very best to everybody.
